description:
The Betta fish, also known as the Siamese fighting fish, is one of the most popular and recognizable freshwater aquarium species in the world. Males are famous for their flowing, ornate fins and vivid coloration, which ranges from deep reds and blues to iridescent greens and purples. They possess a labyrinth organ that allows them to breathe atmospheric air, enabling survival in low-oxygen environments.

Bettas are solitary fish with strong territorial instincts, particularly males, which should never be housed together. Despite their aggressive reputation toward their own kind, individual bettas can be surprisingly personable, often recognizing their owners and displaying engaging behaviors. They are well-suited to nano tanks and desktop aquariums, making them a favorite among hobbyists with limited space.

With proper care, bettas thrive in heated, filtered tanks of at least five gallons. They prefer calm water with minimal current, and benefit from live or silk plants that provide resting spots near the surface. A varied diet of high-quality pellets supplemented with frozen or freeze-dried bloodworms and brine shrimp will keep a betta healthy and vibrant.
temperament: Semi-aggressive; males are territorial toward other males and fish with long, colorful fins
diet: Carnivore — high-protein pellets, frozen or freeze-dried bloodworms, brine shrimp, daphnia
careNotes: Avoid strong currents as bettas prefer calm water. Provide a lid since they can jump. Maintain stable temperatures with a reliable heater. Perform weekly 25% water changes and avoid housing males together or with fin-nipping species.

faqs.question: Can I keep two male bettas together?
faqs.answer: No. Male bettas are highly territorial and will fight, often to the death. Each male must be housed in a separate tank. Female bettas can sometimes be kept in groups of five or more, known as a sorority, but this requires careful planning and a well-planted tank of at least 20 gallons.

faqs.question: Do bettas need a heater and filter?
faqs.answer: Yes. Bettas are tropical fish that require water temperatures between 76-82°F, which almost always requires a heater in home aquariums. A gentle filter is also essential for maintaining water quality, though the flow should be baffled to prevent strong currents that stress bettas.

origin: South America (Peru, Colombia, Brazil — Amazon basin)
description:
The neon tetra is arguably the most iconic freshwater aquarium fish, instantly recognizable by its brilliant iridescent blue stripe running from nose to adipose fin, contrasted by a vivid red stripe along the lower half of its body. These small, peaceful schooling fish create a breathtaking visual display when kept in groups, their colors shimmering as they move in unison through the water column.

Neon tetras are naturally found in blackwater streams and tributaries of the Amazon basin, where the water is soft, acidic, and stained with tannins. In the aquarium, they adapt well to a range of conditions but show their best coloration in dimly lit tanks with dark substrates and plenty of live plants. A school of at least six is essential, though groups of ten or more produce the most natural and visually striking behavior.

These hardy little fish are an excellent choice for beginners and community tank setups. They are peaceful toward virtually all tankmates and occupy the middle levels of the aquarium. Their small bioload makes them suitable for modestly sized tanks, and they readily accept a variety of prepared foods.
temperament: Peaceful; schooling fish that should be kept in groups of 6 or more
diet: Omnivore — micro pellets, flake food, frozen or freeze-dried brine shrimp, daphnia, bloodworms
careNotes: Keep in schools of at least six to reduce stress and encourage natural behavior. Provide subdued lighting and plenty of plants. They are sensitive to rapid changes in water parameters, so acclimate slowly and maintain consistent conditions. Avoid large or aggressive tankmates that may view them as prey.

faqs.question: How many neon tetras should I keep together?
faqs.answer: A minimum of six is recommended, but ten or more is ideal. Neon tetras are obligate schooling fish and become stressed, lose color, and may develop health issues if kept in small numbers. Larger groups also produce much more impressive visual displays.

faqs.question: Why are my neon tetras losing their color?
faqs.answer: Temporary color fading can occur at night (this is normal), during stress from poor water quality, after being recently introduced to a new tank, or when they are kept in too-small groups. Persistent color loss often indicates illness, particularly neon tetra disease, which is unfortunately incurable.

origin: South America (widespread across rivers and streams from Trinidad to Argentina)
description:
Corydoras catfish are among the most endearing and practical additions to any freshwater community aquarium. With their armored bodies, whiskered faces, and perpetual bottom-dwelling activity, these small catfish charm aquarists while performing the valuable service of scavenging uneaten food from the substrate. There are over 160 described species, with popular varieties including the bronze cory, peppered cory, panda cory, and julii cory.

These social fish are happiest in groups and should be kept in schools of at least six, ideally of the same species. They communicate through subtle body language and can often be observed resting together in tight clusters or foraging as a synchronized group across the tank floor. Corydoras are facultative air breathers and will occasionally dart to the surface to gulp air, which is perfectly normal behavior.

Corydoras prefer soft, sandy substrates that will not damage their sensitive barbels. Sharp gravel can cause barbel erosion, leading to infection and reduced ability to find food. A well-planted tank with shaded areas and gentle water flow replicates their natural habitat and encourages natural foraging behavior.
temperament: Very peaceful; social bottom-dweller that schools with its own kind
diet: Omnivore — sinking pellets, wafers, frozen bloodworms, brine shrimp, blanched vegetables
careNotes: Use sand or fine smooth gravel substrate to protect their barbels. Keep in groups of six or more. Ensure sinking food reaches them — corydoras can be outcompeted by faster mid-water feeders. They are sensitive to salt, copper-based medications, and poor substrate hygiene, so vacuum the substrate regularly.

faqs.question: Why does my corydoras keep swimming to the surface?
faqs.answer: Corydoras are facultative air breathers and will occasionally dart to the surface to gulp atmospheric air, which is supplemented through their intestines. Occasional surface trips are perfectly normal. However, if it happens very frequently, it could indicate low dissolved oxygen levels in the tank, and you should check aeration and water quality.

faqs.question: What is the best substrate for corydoras?
faqs.answer: Fine sand is the ideal substrate for corydoras catfish. Their barbels are delicate sensory organs used to sift through substrate in search of food. Sharp or rough gravel can erode and damage these barbels, potentially causing bacterial infections. Pool filter sand and play sand are affordable and popular choices.

origin: South America (Venezuela, Barbados, Trinidad, Guyana); now found worldwide
description:
Guppies are one of the world's most popular aquarium fish and for good reason. Males display a dazzling array of colors and tail shapes that have been refined through decades of selective breeding, ranging from solid reds, blues, and yellows to intricate mosaic, cobra, and snakeskin patterns. Females are larger and more plainly colored but no less important in the hobby.

Renowned for their prolific breeding, guppies are livebearers that can produce a new batch of fry every 25 to 35 days. This reproductive enthusiasm makes them a fantastic species for beginners interested in fish breeding, but it also means population control is a real consideration. Keeping only males prevents unwanted breeding while still providing a colorful display.

Guppies are extremely hardy and adaptable, tolerating a wide range of water parameters. They are active swimmers that occupy the upper and middle levels of the tank, constantly on the move. Their peaceful nature makes them excellent community fish, though their long, flowing tails can attract fin-nipping species, so tankmate selection should be thoughtful.
temperament: Peaceful; active swimmers best kept in groups with a ratio of 2-3 females per male
diet: Omnivore — high-quality flake food, micro pellets, frozen or live brine shrimp, blanched vegetables, spirulina
careNotes: Guppies prefer slightly harder, alkaline water. They are prolific breeders, so keep only males if you want to avoid population explosions. Provide floating plants for fry to hide in if breeding is desired. Avoid housing with known fin nippers like tiger barbs or serpae tetras.

faqs.question: How do I stop my guppies from breeding?
faqs.answer: The simplest method is to keep only males, which still provides a vibrant, colorful display without the constant production of fry. If you have both sexes, separating males and females is the only reliable approach. Some hobbyists add predatory fish to naturally control fry populations, but this is not always effective or humane.

faqs.question: Why are my guppies sitting at the bottom of the tank?
faqs.answer: Guppies are normally active top and mid-level swimmers, so resting on the bottom often signals a problem. Common causes include poor water quality (test ammonia, nitrite, and nitrate immediately), disease (look for clamped fins, spots, or unusual markings), temperature shock, or stress from aggressive tankmates.

origin: South America (Amazon basin — Peru, Colombia, Brazil)
description:
Freshwater angelfish are among the most elegant and graceful fish in the aquarium hobby. Their tall, laterally compressed bodies and elongated dorsal and anal fins give them a majestic, sail-like silhouette that commands attention in any tank. Selective breeding has produced a spectacular range of color morphs including silver, marble, koi, black, gold, and platinum varieties.

As cichlids, angelfish are more intelligent and interactive than many tropical fish. They quickly learn to recognize their keeper and will often approach the glass at feeding time. However, they are also semi-aggressive, particularly as they mature and form breeding pairs. Territorial behavior can escalate during spawning, and they will readily consume fish small enough to fit in their mouths, including neon tetras and small rasboras.

Angelfish require tall tanks to accommodate their body shape, with a minimum height of 18 inches recommended. They appreciate a well-planted aquarium with vertical driftwood and broad-leafed plants like Amazon swords, which also serve as potential spawning sites. A group of juveniles can be raised together, but pairs may become aggressive toward other angelfish as they mature.
temperament: Semi-aggressive; territorial when breeding, may eat very small fish
diet: Omnivore — cichlid pellets, flake food, frozen bloodworms, brine shrimp, mysis shrimp, live foods
size: 6 inches long, up to 10 inches tall
careNotes: Provide a tall tank with plenty of vertical space. Avoid very small tankmates that could become prey. Angelfish are sensitive to poor water quality, so maintain a consistent water change schedule. They can be kept in groups as juveniles but may need to be separated as pairs form and become territorial.

faqs.question: Will angelfish eat neon tetras?
faqs.answer: Yes, adult angelfish will often eat neon tetras and other fish small enough to fit in their mouths. While juvenile angelfish may coexist with small tetras temporarily, as they grow, predation becomes likely. Larger tetra species like congo tetras or lemon tetras are safer companions.

faqs.question: How can I tell if my angelfish are a breeding pair?
faqs.answer: A bonded pair will often separate from the group, claim a territory (usually near a flat vertical surface), and aggressively defend it. They will clean the spawning surface together before egg-laying. You can also observe the breeding tubes (ovipositor and fertilizer tube) becoming visible just before spawning.

origin: South America (Amazon basin — Peru, Brazil, Colombia, French Guiana)
description:
Oscars are large, charismatic cichlids often described as the dogs of the aquarium world due to their remarkable intelligence and interactive personalities. They quickly bond with their owners, often begging for food, following movements outside the tank, and even allowing physical touch. Popular color varieties include tiger, red, albino, and lemon oscars, all featuring the distinctive eyespot (ocellus) on the caudal peduncle.

Despite their endearing behavior, oscars are a serious commitment. They grow rapidly, reaching 12 to 14 inches in length, and require a minimum tank size of 75 gallons for a single fish, with larger tanks strongly recommended for pairs or groups. They are messy eaters with a high bioload, demanding robust filtration and frequent water changes to maintain acceptable water quality.

Oscars are powerful, territorial fish that will rearrange decorations, uproot plants, and can be aggressive toward tankmates. They are best kept with similarly sized, robust fish that can hold their own. Tank setups should feature heavy, stable decorations and strong filtration rated for at least twice the tank volume.
temperament: Aggressive; territorial, will eat smaller fish, may be aggressive toward similarly sized tankmates
diet: Carnivore — cichlid pellets, frozen shrimp, earthworms, crickets, silversides, occasional feeder fish (live feeders not recommended due to disease risk)
tankSize: 75 gallons minimum for one; 125+ gallons for a pair
careNotes: Oscars are incredibly messy eaters that produce a large bioload. Invest in heavy-duty canister filtration and perform 25-30% water changes weekly. Avoid small decorations or gravel that can be swallowed. Do not keep with fish small enough to be eaten. They grow fast — plan for their adult size from the start.

faqs.question: How fast do oscars grow?
faqs.answer: Oscars grow remarkably fast, often reaching 10 inches within their first year if well-fed and housed in adequate space. They can grow approximately one inch per month during their first year. This rapid growth is why it is critical to plan for their adult size from the beginning rather than starting with a small tank.

faqs.question: Can I keep an oscar in a 55-gallon tank?
faqs.answer: A 55-gallon tank is generally considered too small for an adult oscar. While an oscar can physically fit, the limited swimming space and the difficulty of maintaining water quality with such a high-bioload fish in a relatively small volume make it inadvisable. A 75-gallon tank is the bare minimum for a single oscar, with 100+ gallons preferred.

origin: Indo-Pacific (Eastern Indian Ocean, Western Pacific — Indonesia, Philippines, Australia)
description:
The ocellaris clownfish, made famous by a certain animated film, is the most popular marine aquarium fish in the world. Its brilliant orange body marked with three white bars bordered in black is instantly recognizable. Captive-bred specimens are widely available, making this one of the most accessible saltwater species for beginners to the marine hobby.

Clownfish are best known for their symbiotic relationship with sea anemones. In the wild, they live among the stinging tentacles of host anemones, protected by a mucus coating that prevents them from being stung. While an anemone is not required in captivity, many hobbyists enjoy recreating this natural partnership. Suitable host anemones include the magnificent anemone and bubble-tip anemone, though anemone care is significantly more demanding than clownfish care.

All clownfish are born male, with the dominant individual in a group becoming female through sequential hermaphroditism. In a pair, the larger fish is the female and the smaller is the breeding male. They are hardy, disease-resistant, and accept a wide range of prepared foods, making them an excellent first saltwater fish for newcomers to reef keeping.
temperament: Semi-aggressive; territorial around their host anemone or chosen area, but generally peaceful with non-clownfish species
diet: Omnivore — marine pellets, flake food, frozen mysis shrimp, brine shrimp, finely chopped seafood
lifespan: 6-10 years in captivity (up to 20+ in the wild)
careNotes: Captive-bred clownfish are hardier and easier to care for than wild-caught specimens. They do not require an anemone to thrive but may host in soft corals, powerheads, or other tank features. Keep as a single fish or a bonded pair — multiple clownfish in a small tank will fight. Maintain stable salinity at 1.024-1.026 specific gravity.

faqs.question: Do clownfish need an anemone?
faqs.answer: No, clownfish do not require a host anemone to survive and thrive in captivity. Many clownfish live perfectly healthy lives without one. They may adopt substitute hosts such as torch corals, hammer corals, or even powerhead intakes. Anemones have more demanding care requirements than clownfish and are not recommended for beginners.

faqs.question: Can I keep clownfish in a freshwater tank?
faqs.answer: No. Clownfish are strictly marine (saltwater) fish and cannot survive in freshwater. They require a properly established saltwater aquarium with stable salinity, typically at a specific gravity of 1.024-1.026. There is no freshwater alternative or acclimation process that would allow them to live in fresh water.

origin: Sri Lanka (shaded streams and rivers in the Kelani and Nilwala river basins)
description:
The cherry barb is a small, peaceful cyprinid that brings warm color to planted community aquariums. Males develop a deep cherry-red coloration, especially during breeding or when kept in comfortable, well-planted environments, while females display a more subdued brownish-red with a distinctive dark lateral stripe. They are among the most peaceful barb species, lacking the fin-nipping tendencies of their more boisterous relatives.

In the wild, cherry barbs inhabit heavily shaded streams with dense riparian vegetation, which is reflected in their aquarium preferences. They show their best coloration and most natural behavior in tanks with subdued lighting, dark substrates, and plenty of live plants. Floating plants that diffuse overhead light are particularly appreciated.

Cherry barbs are a shoaling rather than a strict schooling species, meaning they prefer the company of their own kind but do not swim in tight formation. A group of at least six is recommended, with a ratio favoring females to reduce male-to-male competition and female harassment. They are excellent community fish that coexist peacefully with a wide variety of similarly sized, gentle species.
temperament: Peaceful; shy shoaling fish that does well in groups of 6 or more
diet: Omnivore — flake food, micro pellets, frozen or live bloodworms, brine shrimp, daphnia, blanched vegetables
careNotes: Provide plenty of plant cover and subdued lighting to bring out their best coloration and reduce stress. Keep in groups of six or more with more females than males (2:1 ratio recommended). They are a listed threatened species in the wild, so only purchase captive-bred specimens.

faqs.question: Are cherry barbs fin nippers?
faqs.answer: No, cherry barbs are one of the most peaceful barb species and are not known for fin nipping. Unlike tiger barbs or serpae tetras, cherry barbs are gentle and can be safely kept with long-finned species like bettas and guppies. Their calm demeanor makes them ideal community tank residents.

faqs.question: Why are my cherry barbs pale?
faqs.answer: Cherry barbs often appear pale when they are stressed, newly introduced to a tank, or kept in bright, sparsely planted setups. Providing dense plant cover, subdued lighting, a dark substrate, and the company of at least six of their own kind will encourage them to display their full cherry-red coloration.

origin: South America (tropical regions of northeastern South America)
description:
The common plecostomus, often simply called a pleco, is one of the most widely sold freshwater aquarium fish, frequently marketed as an algae eater. Covered in bony armored plates and sporting a distinctive sucker mouth, plecos are impressive catfish that attach themselves to surfaces and rasp away at algae and biofilm. They are primarily nocturnal, spending daylight hours hiding in caves and under driftwood before becoming active at dusk.

A critical fact that many new fishkeepers overlook is the eventual adult size of the common pleco. While typically sold at two to three inches, they can grow to 18 to 24 inches in length and live for well over a decade. This makes them wholly unsuitable for the small tanks in which they are often placed. Responsible ownership requires planning for a tank of 100 gallons or more to house an adult common pleco.

For hobbyists with smaller tanks, bristlenose plecos (Ancistrus spp.) are a far more suitable alternative, reaching only four to five inches. Regardless of species, all plecos require driftwood in their tank, as they rasp on it for essential dietary fiber. Their diet should be supplemented with sinking algae wafers and blanched vegetables.
temperament: Peaceful but territorial toward other plecos; largely ignores other fish
diet: Omnivore (primarily herbivore) — algae wafers, blanched zucchini, cucumber, peas, driftwood for fiber, occasional protein from sinking pellets or frozen bloodworms
tankSize: 100 gallons minimum for common pleco; 20 gallons for bristlenose varieties
careNotes: Always provide driftwood, as plecos require wood fiber for proper digestion. They produce a significant bioload and need strong filtration. Feed sinking algae wafers and blanched vegetables — do not rely solely on tank algae for nutrition. Be prepared for their adult size; consider bristlenose plecos for tanks under 75 gallons.

faqs.question: Will a pleco keep my tank clean?
faqs.answer: Plecos eat some algae and biofilm, but they are not a substitute for proper tank maintenance. They produce considerable waste themselves, especially as they grow, and can actually contribute more to the bioload than they offset. You still need regular water changes, proper filtration, and manual algae removal.

faqs.question: Why is my pleco always hiding?
faqs.answer: Plecos are predominantly nocturnal and hiding during the day is completely normal behavior. They emerge at dusk and are most active through the night. Provide plenty of hiding spots such as caves, driftwood, and PVC pipes. If you want to observe feeding, try adding algae wafers or vegetables just before lights out.

origin: South Asia (India, Pakistan, Bangladesh — slow-moving waters with dense vegetation)
description:
The dwarf gourami is a stunningly colorful labyrinth fish that has been a staple of the freshwater aquarium hobby for decades. Males display brilliant alternating stripes of iridescent blue and deep red-orange, while several selectively bred color morphs exist including flame (solid red-orange), powder blue, neon blue, and honey varieties. Females are a more modest silver with faint striping.

Like their relative the betta, dwarf gouramis possess a labyrinth organ that allows them to breathe air from the surface. They are naturally found in densely vegetated, slow-moving waters and rice paddies of South Asia. In the aquarium, they prefer calm water with plenty of floating plants and surface cover, which also encourages their natural bubble-nesting behavior.

Dwarf gouramis are generally peaceful but can be shy, especially when first introduced or if kept with overly active tankmates. Males can be territorial toward each other, so keeping a single male or a male with two females is advisable in smaller tanks. They are susceptible to dwarf gourami iridovirus (DGIV), a concerning disease that has become prevalent in commercially bred stock.
temperament: Peaceful but sometimes shy; males can be territorial toward each other
diet: Omnivore — flake food, small pellets, frozen bloodworms, brine shrimp, daphnia, blanched vegetables
careNotes: Provide floating plants and calm water with minimal surface agitation so they can comfortably access the surface to breathe. Avoid keeping multiple males in small tanks. Be aware of dwarf gourami iridovirus — purchase from reputable sources and quarantine new arrivals. They can be timid, so avoid boisterous tankmates.

faqs.question: Can I keep a dwarf gourami with a betta?
faqs.answer: This combination is generally not recommended. Both species are labyrinth fish with similar territorial instincts, particularly around the water surface. Males of both species may view each other as rivals due to their similar body shapes and bright colors, leading to stress and potential aggression. There are many better tankmate options for both species.

faqs.question: What is dwarf gourami iridovirus?
faqs.answer: Dwarf gourami iridovirus (DGIV) is a viral disease that has become widespread in commercially bred dwarf gouramis. Symptoms include lethargy, loss of color, abdominal swelling, and skin lesions. There is no cure, and the disease is often fatal. Purchasing from reputable breeders and quarantining new fish for 2-4 weeks can reduce the risk.

origin: South Asia (India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar — streams, canals, and rice paddies)
description:
The zebra danio is a small, energetic cyprinid recognized by its distinctive horizontal blue and silver stripes running from gill to tail. These hardy fish are among the most resilient freshwater species available, tolerating a remarkably wide range of temperatures and water parameters. Their toughness, combined with their active schooling behavior and ease of breeding, has also made them one of the most important model organisms in scientific research.

Zebra danios are tireless swimmers that dart constantly through the upper levels of the aquarium. They are fast, agile, and always on the move, which gives the tank a lively, energetic feel. They should be kept in groups of at least six, and their boisterous nature means they may stress slower-moving or timid species. A tank with plenty of open swimming space across the top, complemented by planted areas along the sides and back, suits them perfectly.

Several ornamental varieties have been developed, including long-finned, leopard (spotted rather than striped), and the genetically modified GloFish versions that fluoresce under blue light. All varieties share the same care requirements and hardiness that make the standard zebra danio such a reliable aquarium fish.
temperament: Peaceful but very active; fast swimmers that may stress timid tankmates
diet: Omnivore — flake food, micro pellets, frozen or live brine shrimp, daphnia, bloodworms
tankSize: 10 gallons minimum (long tanks preferred over tall)
careNotes: Provide plenty of horizontal swimming space as they are extremely active surface and mid-level swimmers. Keep in groups of six or more. They are excellent jumpers, so a tight-fitting lid is essential. Their energetic swimming style may stress very shy or slow-moving species, so choose tankmates accordingly.

faqs.question: Can zebra danios live in cold water?
faqs.answer: Zebra danios are remarkably temperature-tolerant and can thrive in temperatures as low as 64°F, making them one of the few tropical fish suitable for unheated tanks in temperate climates. However, they are most active and show the best coloration at temperatures between 70-75°F. They should not be kept in outdoor ponds that experience freezing temperatures.

faqs.question: Why do my zebra danios chase each other?
faqs.answer: Chasing is normal social behavior in zebra danios, particularly among males establishing a dominance hierarchy. This is typically harmless and does not indicate aggression. Keeping a group of six or more distributes this behavior and prevents any single fish from being targeted excessively. If a fish is being isolated and harassed, check that your group size is adequate.

origin: South America (Upper Orinoco and Negro River basins — Venezuela, Brazil, Colombia)
description:
The cardinal tetra is often considered the crown jewel of freshwater schooling fish, featuring an iridescent neon blue stripe running the full length of its body above a brilliant red stripe that extends from head to tail. This distinguishes it from the closely related neon tetra, whose red stripe covers only the posterior half. The result is a fish of exceptional beauty, especially when kept in large schools against a dark, planted background.

Cardinal tetras originate from blackwater habitats — acidic, tannin-stained waters with minimal mineral content. They show their most vivid coloration in aquariums that replicate these conditions, with soft acidic water, a dark substrate, dim lighting, and botanicals like Indian almond leaves or driftwood that release tannins. Many of the cardinal tetras in the hobby are still wild-caught from the Rio Negro, where their sustainable harvest provides vital income to local communities.

While slightly more demanding than neon tetras regarding water parameters, cardinal tetras are still manageable for attentive beginners. They are completely peaceful, occupy the middle water column, and create one of the most visually stunning displays in freshwater aquascaping when kept in groups of fifteen or more.
temperament: Peaceful; timid schooling fish that must be kept in groups of 6 or more
diet: Omnivore — micro pellets, crushed flakes, frozen or live brine shrimp, daphnia, cyclops, bloodworms
careNotes: Cardinals prefer soft, acidic water and show their best colors in blackwater or tannin-rich setups. Add Indian almond leaves or driftwood to naturally lower pH and tint the water. Keep in large groups for the most impressive display and natural behavior. They are sensitive to water quality fluctuations, so maintain stable parameters and perform regular small water changes.

faqs.question: What is the difference between cardinal tetras and neon tetras?
faqs.answer: The most visible difference is the extent of the red stripe. Cardinal tetras have a red stripe that runs the entire length of the body from head to tail, while neon tetras have red only on the posterior half. Cardinals are also slightly larger, prefer softer and more acidic water, and tend to be more expensive. Both species are peaceful schooling fish suitable for community tanks.

faqs.question: Why are cardinal tetras more expensive than neon tetras?
faqs.answer: Many cardinal tetras are still wild-caught from the Rio Negro in Brazil, whereas neon tetras are almost exclusively captive-bred in large commercial facilities in Southeast Asia. Wild collection, shipping, and higher mortality rates during transport contribute to the higher retail price. Captive-bred cardinals are becoming more available and tend to be more affordable and hardier.

origin: South America (Orinoco River basin — Venezuela, Colombia)
description:
The German blue ram is widely regarded as one of the most beautiful freshwater fish in the aquarium hobby. This dwarf cichlid displays a stunning palette of iridescent blues, yellows, and oranges, with distinctive black markings including a prominent vertical bar through the eye and a dark spot on the flank. Males develop extended dorsal fin rays and more intense coloration, while females display a pink-red belly when in breeding condition.

Despite their small size, German blue rams possess the full personality of their larger cichlid relatives. They form monogamous pairs, establish territories, and exhibit complex breeding behaviors including substrate preparation, egg guarding, and biparental care of fry. Their intelligence and interactive behavior make them a favorite among aquarists who appreciate fish with character.

German blue rams are more sensitive to water quality than many commonly kept tropical fish. They require warm, soft, acidic water and are intolerant of elevated nitrate levels. A mature, well-maintained aquarium with stable parameters is essential. While not suited for beginners, they reward experienced hobbyists with stunning beauty and captivating behavior.
temperament: Peaceful for a cichlid; mildly territorial when breeding but generally compatible with community fish
diet: Omnivore — high-quality small pellets, frozen bloodworms, brine shrimp, daphnia, cyclops, occasional live foods
careNotes: German blue rams require warmer temperatures than most tropical fish (80-86°F), which limits compatible tankmates. They are very sensitive to ammonia, nitrite, and elevated nitrate — maintain nitrate below 20 ppm. Provide sand substrate with flat rocks or broad leaves for potential spawning sites. Avoid purchasing cheaply mass-produced specimens, as they are often genetically weakened and prone to disease.

faqs.question: Why do German blue rams keep dying?
faqs.answer: German blue rams are sensitive fish that commonly die from poor water quality (especially nitrate buildup), temperatures that are too low, or genetic weakness from mass commercial breeding. Ensure your tank is fully cycled, maintain temperatures at 80-86°F, keep nitrates below 20 ppm, and purchase from reputable breeders who prioritize health over volume.

faqs.question: Can German blue rams be kept with other dwarf cichlids?
faqs.answer: German blue rams can coexist with other peaceful dwarf cichlids like Apistogramma species in sufficiently large, well-decorated tanks (30+ gallons) where each pair can establish their own territory. Provide ample visual barriers using plants, rocks, and driftwood. However, combining multiple dwarf cichlid species in small tanks often leads to territorial conflicts.

origin: South America (Brazil, Bolivia, Paraguay — slow-moving rivers and swamps)
description:
Mystery snails are large, attractive freshwater snails that have become enormously popular in the aquarium hobby for their algae-eating abilities, fascinating behavior, and beautiful shell colors. Available in a range of colors including gold, ivory, blue, magenta, jade, and wild-type brown, their round shells and gentle demeanor make them a delightful addition to almost any community tank.

Unlike many pest snail species, mystery snails will not devour live aquarium plants. They primarily feed on algae, biofilm, detritus, and decaying plant matter, making them excellent tank cleaners. They are also surprisingly entertaining to watch, using their long siphon to breathe at the surface, extending their tentacles to explore, and occasionally floating or "surfing" on the current.

Mystery snails are one of the few aquarium snail species that lay their eggs above the waterline, depositing distinctive pink or white egg clutches on the tank lid, light fixtures, or just above the waterline. This reproductive strategy makes population control much easier than with other snails, as unwanted egg clutches can simply be removed before they hatch.
temperament: Completely peaceful; harmless to all tankmates and live plants
diet: Omnivore (primarily herbivore) — algae wafers, blanched vegetables (zucchini, spinach, cucumber), calcium-rich foods, decaying plant matter, biofilm
careNotes: Provide calcium-rich water and supplemental calcium (cuttlebone, calcium blocks, or crushed coral in the filter) to ensure healthy shell growth. Avoid acidic water below pH 7.0, as it erodes their shells. They are sensitive to copper, which is found in many fish medications — check labels carefully. Remove egg clutches above the waterline if you do not want baby snails.

faqs.question: Will mystery snails eat my live plants?
faqs.answer: Mystery snails (Pomacea bridgesii) are plant-safe and will not eat healthy live plants. They feed on algae, biofilm, and decaying plant matter. This distinguishes them from apple snails (Pomacea canaliculata), which are voracious plant eaters. Make sure you are purchasing the correct species if plant safety is a concern.

faqs.question: Why is my mystery snail floating?
faqs.answer: Floating is common in mystery snails and is usually harmless. They often trap air in their shells deliberately to float to a new location or ride the current. If the snail has been floating for an extended period (24+ hours) and is not responsive when gently touched, it may be ill or deceased. A deceased mystery snail will produce a strong, unmistakable odor.

origin: Japan, Taiwan (freshwater streams that flow to the ocean)
description:
The Amano shrimp, named after legendary aquascaper Takashi Amano who popularized their use in planted aquariums, is the most effective algae-eating shrimp available in the freshwater hobby. These transparent to light grey shrimp are marked with rows of distinctive dots and dashes along their sides, and they can grow larger than most other freshwater aquarium shrimp, reaching up to two inches in length.

Amano shrimp are prized for their voracious appetite for nearly all types of algae, including the notoriously difficult-to-eradicate hair algae and brush algae that most other algae eaters ignore. A group of Amano shrimp can transform an algae-plagued tank in a matter of weeks. They are constantly active, methodically picking at every surface in the tank with their small claws.

While Amano shrimp are easy to keep in freshwater, breeding them in captivity is extremely difficult. Their larvae require brackish to full saltwater to survive, and the rearing process is complex and time-consuming. As a result, most Amano shrimp in the hobby are wild-caught. They are peaceful, hardy invertebrates that coexist well with small, non-predatory fish and other shrimp species.
temperament: Completely peaceful; may compete with fish for food at feeding time but poses no threat
diet: Omnivore — algae (primary diet), biofilm, decaying plant matter, algae wafers, blanched vegetables, shrimp-specific foods
careNotes: Amano shrimp are sensitive to copper and heavy metals — avoid copper-based medications and use a water conditioner that detoxifies heavy metals. They are excellent escape artists and may climb out of uncovered tanks, especially at night. Keep in groups of at least five for the best algae control. Supplement their diet with algae wafers if the tank does not have sufficient natural algae growth.

faqs.question: How many Amano shrimp do I need for algae control?
faqs.answer: A general guideline is one Amano shrimp per two to three gallons of tank water, or about three to five shrimp per ten gallons. For tanks with significant algae problems, you may want to start with a higher density. Keep in mind that Amano shrimp are social and do best in groups of at least five, regardless of tank size.

faqs.question: Can Amano shrimp breed in freshwater?
faqs.answer: Amano shrimp will mate and produce eggs in freshwater, but the larvae cannot survive without brackish or saltwater conditions. The larvae go through several planktonic stages that require gradually increasing salinity and specific feeding with microscopic organisms. Breeding Amano shrimp in captivity is possible but very challenging, which is why most are wild-caught.
